raw_text:
Blair ready to call election
 
 Tony Blair seems certain to end weeks of phoney war on Monday and announce there will be a general election on 5 May.
 
 The date has been pencilled into the diaries of politicians and political journalists for many months and, despite occasional panics that the prime minister was on the verge of calling a snap poll, it has not shifted. Over the weeks, there have been any number of signs that 050505 was going to be the day Mr Blair would go for an historic third term. And the calling of a special political cabinet meeting has only added to the belief that the announcement is imminent. The prime minister and his campaign boss Alan Milburn have already insisted the election will be fought on the economy and what they claim is a stark choice between Labour's stability and investment against Tory cuts and boom and bust.
 
 And Chancellor Gordon Brown has stepped into the front line of the campaign - to the relief of many of his supporters in Westminster - to underline that economic message. And it is certain one of the big arguments at the centre of the election battle will be around the big parties' tax and spend policies.
 
 During the phoney campaign, Labour got into trouble over its central claim that Michael Howard was planning £35 bn cuts in public services. The prime minister found himself struggling to explain how a smaller, slower increase in spending planned by the Tories compared to Labour's plans was a cut. And it looked like the Labour campaign - which was already being criticised for being thrown into defensive mode by Mr Howard on issues such as immigration and health - was on the rocks. Then deputy Conservative Chairman Howard Flight was reported to have suggested Mr Howard was secretly planning even bigger "cuts".
 
 He was sacked for his gaffe, but the damage had been done and the faltering Labour campaign was back on track. A second central argument will be over taxation, with the Tories claiming the Chancellor has to fill a black hole at the centre of his finances and will be forced to raise taxes if Labour wins again. Mr Brown slaps that aside, claiming his forecasts are accurate and that previous claims of looming economic disaster have proved inaccurate. As usual, the Liberal Democrats will have to fight to get their voice heard over the sounds of battle between the two big parties. But leader Charles Kennedy believes he has set out a distinctive manifesto with plans for a tax rise for the wealthiest to finance extra spending and the abolition of the council tax in favour of a local income tax. Other issues are certain to play a part - immigration and asylum, the war on Iraq, law and order and education, for example. But, as ever, it will be the economy that will almost certainly decide the outcome. And, whatever that outcome, 2005 is set to be a far more lively, even bitter campaign than 2001's non-event.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair is ready to announce a general election on May 5, despite weeks of speculation about whether he would call it earlier.
The announcement will come after Chancellor Gordon Brown steps in to address the economic message with his own party's tax and spend policies.
Labour faces opposition from both parties over issues such as taxation and spending cuts, while Charles Kennedy's Liberal Democrats are also campaigning on various fronts.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair announces planned general election for May 5, setting up battle with Labour on economic policies against Tory cuts and boom and bust.
Chancellor Gordon Brown underlines message, while Labour claims Tories are secretly planning bigger cuts.
Campaign will focus on tax and spend policies, with Liberal Democrats seeking to differentiate themselves with plans for a local income tax and extra spending.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair is expected to announce a general election on May 5th.
The election will focus on economic policies with Labour highlighting stability and investment while the Tories emphasize cuts.
Chancellor Gordon Brown is taking the lead in defending Labour’s economic policies, while the Liberal Democrats are seeking a distinct platform.
The election promises to be more contested than in 2001.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Blair announces general election on May 5 Blair wants election but won't call snap poll Blair announced general election with new cabinet Gordon Brown to fight for Labour party tax and spending policies Charles Kennedy will present manifesto Charlie Hebdomadares will debate the economy Blair wants to improve economy but won't call snap poll Tony Blair says he's ready for an election on May 5, 2019
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair likely to announce general election on May 5th after weeks of speculation following recent economic arguments and tax policy debates between the two main parties.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Blair seems certain to announce a general election on May 5th, focusing on economic issues such as Labour’s stability and investment versus the Tories’ cuts and instability.
The election will also highlight tax and spending policies.
Despite initial challenges with public service cuts and immigration issues, Labour's campaign is now focused on addressing these concerns through their economic message.
Economic arguments will be central to the election battle, including whether taxes need to rise or remain constant.
The Liberal Democrats are expected to compete for voters' attention alongside the main parties.
The economy is widely seen as the deciding factor in this likely more contentious 2005 campaign compared to 2001.
opencoder:1.5b:
Blair ready to call election

Tony Blair seems certain to end weeks of phony war on Monday and announce there will be a general election on 5 May.

The date has been pencilled into the diaries of politicians and political journalists for many months and, despite occasional panics that the prime minister was on the verge of calling a snap poll, it has not shifted.
Over the weeks, there have been any number of signs that 050505 was going to be the day Mr Blair would go for an historic third term.
And the calling of a special political cabinet meeting has only added to the belief that the announcement is imminent.

The prime minister and his campaign boss Alan Milburn have already insisted the election will be fought on the economy and what they claim is a stark choice between Labour's stability and investment against Tory cuts and boom and bust.
And Chancellor Gordon Brown has stepped into the front line of the campaign - to the relief of many of his supporters in Westminster - to underline that economic message.
During the phoney campaign, Labour got into trouble over its central claim that Michael Howard was planning £35 bn cuts in public services.
The prime minister found himself struggling to explain how a smaller, slower increase in spending planned by the Tories compared to Labour's plans was a cut.
He looked like the Labour campaign - which was already beingcritiqued for being thrown into defensive mode by Mr Howard on issues such as immigration and health - was on the rocks.
Then deputy Conservative chairman Howard Flight was reported to have suggested Mr Howard was secretly planning bigger "cuts".
He was sacked for his gaffe, but the damage had been done and the faltering Labour campaign was back on track.
A second central argument will be over taxation, with the Tories claiming the Chancellor has to fill a black hole at the centre of his finances and will be forced to raise taxes if Labour wins again.
Mr Brown slaps that aside, claiming his forecasts are accurate and that previous claims of looming economic disaster have proved inaccurate.
As usual, the Liberal Democrats will have to fight to get their voice heard over the sounds of battle between the two big parties.

But leader Charles Kennedy believes he has set out a distinctive manifesto with plans for a tax rise for the wealthiest to finance extra spending and the abolition of the council tax in favour of a local income tax.
Other issues are certain to play a part - immigration and asylum, the war on Iraq, law and order and education, for example.
But, as ever, it will be the economy that will almost certainly decide the outcome.
And, whatever that outcome, 2005 is set to be a far more lively, even bitter campaign than 2001's non-event.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details:

1.
Blair ready to call election: The prime minister has announced his intention to call an election on May 5th.

Tony Blair seems certain to end weeks of phoney war on Monday: There is no indication that the prime minister will be calling a general election, but it is clear that he is confident in his ability to win again.

The date has been pencilled into the diaries of politicians and political journalists for many months: The prime minister's campaign strategy has been well-documented over the years, including his plans for a tax rise and abolition of council tax.

Over the weeks, there have been any number of signs that 050505 was going to be the day Mr Blair would go for an historic third term: There are no indications that the prime minister will be calling an election on May 5th, but it is clear that he has a strong case for re-election.

The Labour party's economic message is likely to be a key factor in the election campaign: The Labour party has been campaigning hard over its economic policies, and it is clear that they will be a central issue in the election.

Gordon Brown has stepped into the front line of the campaign - to the relief of many of his supporters in Westminster: The Labour party's leader has been heavily involved in the campaign, and it is clear that he has a strong case for re-election.

The Tories' central argument will be over taxation, with the Labour party claiming that they have more control over the economy than the Tories: The Labour party has been campaigning hard on its economic policies, and it is clear that they will be a key issue in the election.
Mr Brown slaps aside Labour's gaffe: The prime minister's campaign strategy has been well-documented over the years, including his plans for a tax rise and abolition of council tax.

The Liberal Democrats' manifesto sets out a distinctive plan to finance extra spending and abolish council tax: The Liberal Democrats have been campaigning hard on their economic policies, and it is clear that they will be a key issue in the election.

Other issues are certain to play a part in the election campaign: There are no indications that the economy will decide the outcome of the election, but there are other issues that will be important for voters to consider.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Blair is set for an election on May 5th, with early hopes and plans building up in diaries.
The election likely hinges on economic policies between Labour's stability and Tory cuts and boom/bust.
Prime Minister Blair and his boss Milburn focus on the economy, while Chancellor Gordon Brown presents a case for policy changes like tax increases to counter Labour's potential win.
The Conservative campaign is struggling with issues but faces rebuilding support due to Howard Flight's gaffe.
The election will be driven by economic arguments, with Blair's focus on balance and Brown's emphasis on forecasts.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Prime Minister and his Chancellor have both stated their intentions to announce a general election on 5 May, with Labour claiming that this will be an historic third term for the United Kingdom.
The campaign has been marked by signs of panic over possible tax increases, as well as debates about the big parties' policy proposals in areas such as health and education.

The Liberal Democrats also argue that a lack of economic growth threatens their manifesto plans, but Charles Kennedy believes his manifestos will be "distinctive" and make unique promises to finance extra spendings.
As ever, the economy is set to dominate the election campaign, with immigration and Iraq likely to feature in arguments.
Despite several signs that 05/05/2005 is already a forgone conclusion, the election will almost certainly be more exciting and lively than 2001's non-event.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Blair ready to call election: Tony Blair, Prime Minister of Britain, has confirmed that there will be a general election on May 5th, regardless of the outcome of negotiations between the two main opposition parties.
The timing of this announcement is significant as it follows a series of pencilled-in dates and marked changes in political strategies by both Mr Blair and his campaign boss Alan Milburn.
This decision to call an election comes amidst claims that the Labour party will be in power for a third term following the general election.
phi:2.7b: Tony Blair plans to call a general election on May 5th, with a focus on the economy and a stark choice between Labour's stability and investment vs Tory cuts and economic instability.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has already emphasized this message.
A central argument will be over the tax and spend policies of the two big parties.
However, the Labour campaign was thrown into defensive mode by Conservative Deputy Chairman Howard Flight, who suggested he planned bigger cuts than the Tories.
Mr Blair denied these claims, but it is likely that other issues such as immigration and education will also play a role in the election.
Ultimately, it is the economy that will determine the outcome of the election.
orca-mini:3b: Blair prepares for election on May 5th.
Blair's government has been in place since 1997 and he wants to win a third term.
The date of the election has been penciled in for weeks, and Blair has been hinting that it will happen soon.
He believes that the election will be fought on the economy, with him arguing that the Tories plan to cut public services by £35 billion.
Labour's spending plans are smaller and slower, but Tory plans are even bigger and require higher taxes.
The Liberal Democrats will have a difficult time getting their message heard amidst the two big parties' arguments.
hermes3:3b: Tony Blair likely to announce general election on 5th May.

Key arguments: 
- Labour vs Tory tax and spend policies
- Economic plans by both parties
- Potential issues like immigration, war on Iraq etc.
but mainly focus will be on economy.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Tony Blair is expected to announce a general election on May 5th, following signs of a Labour win for a third term.
The election will focus on the economy with key parties' tax and spend policies at the center of arguments.
The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, underlined this message during the campaign, while the Liberal Democrats will fight to get their voice heard amidst the intensified political climate.
The outcome is likely to be determined by the economy, making it a crucial deciding factor in the election.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Tony Blair is expected to announce a general election for 5 May, ending weeks of speculation.
The campaign will focus on the economy, with Labour emphasizing stability and investment, while the Conservatives argue for tax cuts and accuse Labour of financial mismanagement.
Chancellor Gordon Brown has taken a central role in defending Labour’s economic record.
Labour faced early difficulties over claims about Tory spending cuts but regained momentum after a Conservative official suggested deeper cuts were planned.
The Tories argue Labour will need to raise taxes, while the Liberal Democrats propose tax increases for the wealthy and replacing council tax with a local income tax.
Other key issues include immigration, Iraq, law and order, and education, but the economy is expected to be the decisive factor in what is predicted to be a heated campaign.
stablelm2:1.6b: Tony Blair is likely to call an election for May 5th, amidst signs that he would make history with a third term.
Politicians and journalists have been planning the event for months.

The key issues for the election will include economy, investment vs. cuts in public services, tax and spend policies, Labour's and Conservatives' finances, immigration, asylum, war on Iraq, law and order, education, and the economy as a whole.
It is expected to be an intense campaign dominated by these topics.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair is expected to announce on Monday, 5 May, a general election, following weeks of speculation.
The date has been confirmed by politicians and journalists for months.

The election will focus on the economy, with Labour and Conservatives presenting contrasting economic strategies: Labour promising stability and investment, while the Conservatives threaten Tory cuts and boom-bust cycles.
Chancellor Gordon Brown will lead the Labour campaign's economic message.

A key point of contention has been Labour's claim that Michael Howard plans £35 billion in public service cuts, which was debunked when deputy Conservative Chairman Howard Flight suggested even larger cuts.
This incident temporarily weakened the Labour campaign but did not deter it from regaining momentum.
Taxation will also be a significant issue, with the Conservatives arguing that Brown's forecasts are unrealistic and he'll raise taxes if re-elected.
Brown disputes this, citing past inaccurate economic predictions.
The Liberal Democrats' manifesto will aim to secure attention for their plans, including a tax rise for the wealthy to fund increased spending and replacing council tax with a local income tax.
Other topics, such as immigration, the Iraq War, law enforcement, and education, are expected to feature prominently.
However, the economy is anticipated to sway voters' decisions.
This election is poised to be more intense and contentious than 2001's non-event campaign.
